story:
You're Never Truly Lost When You Are

"At Home At Sea"

My name is E.G. Phillips.  I'm a singer-songwriter based out of San Francisco.  I write jazz-infused indie-folk music with lyrics that have been described as both cinematic and whimsical.  I've recently completed a new full length album which I'll be releasing in early 2019 which I've dubbed "At Home At Sea."  I'm offering it for pre-sale to mitigate all the costs involved in an admittedly ambitious plan that includes creating two music videos.

 

About The Album

The album includes songs that I've been playing live at venues around the Bay Area for the past few years.  They have proved to be popular with audiences and I'm really excited about the the results of my collaboration with Ben Osheroff who recorded and produced the album. 

As befits my own musical tastes, it's a rather bohemian menagerie.  In addition to the jazzier numbers that make up the majority of the album, there's also a bossa nova tune, a rock epic, and a haunting soundscape.  The instrumentation is eclectic and varied — with a steel guitar, trumpets, baritone saxes, trombones, mandolins, violins, and even ukuleles all joining the fray at various points.

These are songs about dealing with and managing loneliness, longing and heartache.  They are all tunes I love and they've helped me many a day get through what Douglas Adams once described as that "Long Dark Tea-Time of the Soul" and other moments of lowness.   Performing a rousing rendition of "The Albatross Song" and getting audiences singing along at my gig at the Hotel Carlton once a week has been a life saver for me (you get a small taste of this through the opening choral segment actually recorded at a performance at the Lost Church last July).

So I'm passionate about these songs and want to give them their best chance to be heard by as many people as possible, as niche as my brand of music may be.  And releasing new music, especially an, is an opportunity to get people's attention and grow as an artist,  I've done what I can to minimize my costs overall, such as doing my own artwork, but ultimately this sort of promotion, along with recording, costs money.   By contributing to this campaign, you'll be helping me spread the word and evangelize this music as well as create some more fun and engaging works of art. 

Specifically, I'm producing music videos to help visualize these songs and get them more exposure through social media.  Additionally I'll be creating physical media to send to radio stations as well as merchandise that I can sell at shows such as t-shirts, magnets and stickers. 

Putting something out there and not having it be noticed at all is one of the most dispiriting aspects of creating anything.  And getting heard above the din of all the noise that's out there is no easy feat, so that's why I'm asking for your help.

The costs feel overwhelming on an individual level, but with just a little support from you, it will start to seem more doable and that I have some real support for this endeavor and what I've created.  The goal is ambitious, probably a stretch, but just having you throwing something in would mean a lot.

 

About Me

As Dylan says "I come from a country called the Midwest" — though I've been out in the Bay Area for over two decades now.  Still my sensibilities are such that I think there's just something wrong about corn that's not on a cob and not been bought fresh at a roadside stand.  I am in possession of a degree in Geography, I'm a big fan of Doctor Who (it exercises an outsized influence on my oeuvre), and as you might have gathered, I do a bit of painting.    

As far as music goes, I primarily consider myself to be a songwriter, but I've become much more active as a performer, especially over the past year.  I primarily play live in the Bay Area at venues such as Bazaar Cafe, the Hotel Utah, and the Lost Church, but I've also performed down in Los Angeles and out in Nashville.  I'm quite involved in our local music community here in San Francisco by being a part of our open mic scene and going regularly to our chapter of the musician meet up group "Balanced Breakfast."  I play weekly at the Hotel Carlton as a part of "Local Vocals" and I've volunteered with "Bread and Roses Presents" to play for patients at the psych ward of SF General.   I've also organized ensemble events such as tributes to Tom Lehrer and Bob Dylan (some of my musical heroes) — not to mention my own birthday celebration, EGPhest — to bring together a diverse set of performers from all the individuals I've gotten to know since I first started actively playing out half a dozen years ago or so.

I come to all these music related endeavors later in life than is typical, and am really still just getting started.  I only released my first album, "Fish from the Sky" just a few years ago, well into my 41st year.  I have had the guitar since college (note I did say I have *played* guitar since college) and until comparatively recently, I mainly dabbled.  I wrote quite a bit that I kept to myself, but I lived a different life before all of this, being something of a refugee from the world of tech these days.  So I'm no musical prodigy by any means, but I bring some lived experience and a life long love for language to my lyrics (early on I was dictating to my parents the words of speech balloons I'd placed in my drawings).  An affinity for classic jazz, British Invasion rock and a wide variety of genres has led me developing my own distinctive palette when it comes to creating melody and harmony. 

You can find out more about myself and my music at http://duckswithpants.com — Ducks With Pants being the name of my fake/sometimes real band.

 

 

What You're Money Goes Towards

In order to help you understand why I've created a pre-order campaign and what your money is helping to fund, below is a break down of the different components parts and costs I need to cover.  Given that I've previously released an album as well as two singles with videos, I have experience as to what all is involved and where some of the costs come from.   I've chosen flexible funding so I can evaluate where I want to put my resources when the campaign is over.

 

Physical Media Creation and Distribution

Although physical media is much, much less important these days as a source of profit for artists (who even owns CD player?), there is still a benefit to creating it.  While there is something quite nice about having a physical artifact,  the primarily purpose in this case is for distribution to radio stations, which still prefer that format for maintaining their catalogue.  I will be targeting the distribution of the album to college and independent radio stations. 

I'll be using Disc Makers to create 300 copies of the album using a 4 panel "digipak" layout which is a bit no frills, but is lightweight for mailing and also provides a spine with space for the artist name and album title which radio stations require as they tend to store them on shelves like books on a bookcase.  As a line item, this comes to $700.

Along with the cost of creating the CD, there is also the cost of mailers and postage as well as printing labels and "one sheets" on decent quality paper which provide information about myself as an artist.    To be conservative, I'm assuming $3 per mailing for 200 CDs.

I consider this, along with a nominal amount of money dedicated to ads / boosting posts on social media — which add up and are a necessary evil to get your content seen (even by people who have already "liked" you ... but don't get me started).  This includes promoting this IndieGoGo campaign.  to be a basic cost to promoting the album and getting the word out.  Overall, this represents about 9% of the overall campaign objective.

I'll be offering a limited number of CDs, which I will sign, as a perk.  The rest will be sent to music managers at radio stations across the country.

 

Promotional Swag

I'm going to be creating merchandise related to this release that will include t-shirts, magnets and stickers.   These represent a good basic set of merch items that I think people will enjoy and be most likely to buy.  These items will use the artwork and logo I've designed for the album.  I want to do a run of these items of a sufficient size to make them as cost effective as I can. 

Below is the design I've created for the t-shirts based on the original acrylic painting used for the album artwork as a five color vector image appropriate for silk screen printing (well, 6 colors, but one is made transparent depending upon the t-shirt color).  To make the printing more economical it's actually 4 colors and half tones are used where possible — this leads to some subtle variations, but I think it's cool.

As part of this campaign, I'm offering these items as perks as well.  Since there is a significant price break with the vendor I'm using at 125 t-shirts, this the number I costed out for each of the two styles I'm creating when I came up with the campaign budget (The assumption is that  some will be pre-ordered and I'll want to have decent initial inventory for the various sizes).  Similar considerations are in play for the magnets and stickers.  The swag items represents approximately 16% of the overall campaign target. 

 

Music Videos

One of the primary objectives of this campaign will be to help fund the production of two music videos associated with this album.  Creating a compelling visual component is one of the most effective means to get people aware of and engaged with new music.  It also offers opportunities for additional exposure through other channels such as film festivals.  Furthermore it's just something I enjoy doing.

By pre-ordering, in addition to supporting myself and this album, you'll also be supporting the independent artists that will be helping me create these videos. 

Given some particular opportunities available to me, I've already started to move forward with these projects.  For instance, I've already shot some footage for a live action video for the "The Albatross Song" because a fantastic and visually sumptuous location was available to me for this shoot in December.  The host of this venue helped make the affair into a community building event with an open mic for local musicians in order to create the sort of crowd atmosphere I wanted for this piece.  It was a great night and I'm looking forward to seeing the results as the videographer starts editing the footage together. 

I'm also working with an artist to create a video for "Lighthouse at the Edge of the World" that I will be releasing as single before the release of the full album.  This video will combine animation with live video featuring the California Coast.  

Developing professional quality videos is expensive.  In addition to the cost of hiring a videographer or animator and other personnel and production costs, there is the further cost of promoting the videos on social media to help get the visibility and the engagement this work deserves.  

Having released music videos in the past, I know from experience simply posting them isn't enough to get views — the various social platforms make it a lot harder to go "viral" these days and having spent money and time creating these pieces, it's worth planning in costs to promote them as well.  Fortunately, I now have data points from previous Facebook ad campaigns that will help me target audiences more effectively for these releases for a DIY approach to promotion (for a more "advanced" campaign option I am considering, see below).  In addition to purchasing Facebook and Instagram ads to promote these videos, I will be submitting them to various film festivals for which there are not insignificant entry fees and can add up as you select multiple categories — for instance for the Berlin Music Video festival I'm aiming to submit the video for Lighthouse at the Edge of the World, to enter both the "Best Animation" and "Best Video Category" will run me $60.  I've factored in these costs into the video creation budget.

To get a sense of my creative vision when it comes to music videos, here is a previous video that I self funded:

The L.A. Song

(This video shot in Los Angeles with Button Up Productions)
 

The cost of producing the music videos and doing a social media campaign accounts for over a quarter of the fundraising objective.  The costs are split between the two new videos, with the live action video taking a somewhat larger share of the budget than the animated video.

 

Advanced Promotional Costs

I'm looking to engage a professional PR firm to help me garner press for the album as well place place singles and the videos in music blogs and playlists.  These campaigns run over the course of a number of weeks or months and are quite expensive — although the pricing varies depending upon the agency as does what services are included in various packages they offer.  However something along the lines of ~$1300  month for a minimum of 3 months is a common price point, though there are usually lower cost options.  In doing this sort of promotion I would expect to also need to do a professional photoshoot which is going to run around $300.  So I've budgeted a quarter of my fundraising goal towards this portion of the campaign.

There is debate within the music community as to the efficacy of using such agencies, but I feel that given the effort I've put into the music, I owe it and myself the opportunity that someone with real expertise can provide in finding it an audience.  

 

Recording Costs

Then there's the money it took to create the album itself.

The remaining approximately 24% of the campaign budget will go towards the cost of recording, mastering and digital distribution of the album and its singles.  Recouping these costs will allow me to engage in future recording projects.

 

Risks

Since at this point the music is already recorded, there's no risk that you won't receive the music as a digital download.  But by buying the music as a pre-order, you'll be helping with its release into world in a way that will help me maximize its exposure and success.  

With the music videos there are inherent risks in the creative process — such as being subject to schedules of other creatives involved.  But at this point we already have a significant amount of footage for the first video done so it's largely a matter of editing at this point.  I expect the initial edit to be completed in mid-late January.  We are still in the early stages of the 2nd video's production, but we have an end date scheduled for early February to target a particular film festival.

Some of the merch items might end up varying slightly as I inevitably end up tweak them a bit (especially in regards to the t-shirts), but I don't expect the basic design choices to change.

Even if I meet my fundraising goals, allowing me to do the full PR campaign, there's no guarantee that such a promotional campaign will result in placements and the resulting additional exposure I'm looking for.  However, by helping with the campaign you'll be showing there's interest in my music and contributing to the overall story of how this music came to be.

If I don't reach my funding goal, the promotional efforts will need to be scaled back and I will likely reassess the number of swag items I end up ordering.  Fortunately I took advantage of an IndieGoGo promotional discount so the fees for not hitting my goal are much less substantive.

 

And Any Extra I Get?

Extra money I receive above and beyond my target will be used in part towards ordering more swag so I can have it available as merch at shows and for selling on-line via bandcamp.  And for certain pieces, such as the magnets, there's a significant price break to be had for ordering in bulk beyond my current plan.

Additionally, the more I receive, the more robust the online marketing campaign can be.  The more I can spend on a PR campaign, the better chance I'll have at placing the songs and videos in music blogs and Spotify playlists to reach a wider audience.

Beyond that, you will be helping to fund my next recording project.

Thank you for your support.

- E.G.

  As far as music goes, I primarily consider myself to be a songwriter, but I've become much more active as a performer, especially over the past year.  I primarily play live in the Bay Area at venues such as Bazaar Cafe, the Hotel Utah, and the Lost Church, but I've also performed down in Los Angeles and out in Nashville.  I'm quite involved in our local music community here in San Francisco by being a part of our open mic scene and going regularly to our chapter of the musician meet up group "Balanced Breakfast."  I play weekly at the Hotel Carlton as a part of "Local Vocals" and I've volunteered with "Bread and Roses Presents" to play for patients at the psych ward of SF General.   I've also organized ensemble events such as tributes to Tom Lehrer and Bob Dylan (some of my musical heroes) — not to mention my own birthday celebration, EGPhest — to bring together a diverse set of performers from all the individuals I've gotten to know since I first started actively playing out half a dozen years ago or so.I come to all these music related endeavors later in life than is typical, and am really still just getting started.  I only released my first album, "Fish from the Sky" just a few years ago, well into my 41st year.  I have had the guitar since college (note I did say I have *played* guitar since college) and until comparatively recently, I mainly dabbled.  I wrote quite a bit that I kept to myself, but I lived a different life before all of this, being something of a refugee from the world of tech these days.  So I'm no musical prodigy by any means, but I bring some lived experience and a life long love for language to my lyrics (early on I was dictating to my parents the words of speech balloons I'd placed in my drawings).  An affinity for classic jazz, British Invasion rock and a wide variety of genres has led me developing my own distinctive palette when it comes to creating melody and harmony. You can find out more about myself and my music at http://duckswithpants.com — Ducks With Pants being the name of my fake/sometimes real band.  What You're Money Goes TowardsIn order to help you understand why I've created a pre-order campaign and what your money is helping to fund, below is a break down of the different components parts and costs I need to cover.  Given that I've previously released an album as well as two singles with videos, I have experience as to what all is involved and where some of the costs come from.   I've chosen flexible funding so I can evaluate where I want to put my resources when the campaign is over. 
Physical Media Creation and Distribution
Although physical media is much, much less important these days as a source of profit for artists (who even owns CD player?), there is still a benefit to creating it.  While there is something quite nice about having a physical artifact,  the primarily purpose in this case is for distribution to radio stations, which still prefer that format for maintaining their catalogue.  I will be targeting the distribution of the album to college and independent radio stations. I'll be using Disc Makers to create 300 copies of the album using a 4 panel "digipak" layout which is a bit no frills, but is lightweight for mailing and also provides a spine with space for the artist name and album title which radio stations require as they tend to store them on shelves like books on a bookcase.  As a line item, this comes to $700.Along with the cost of creating the CD, there is also the cost of mailers and postage as well as printing labels and "one sheets" on decent quality paper which provide information about myself as an artist.    To be conservative, I'm assuming $3 per mailing for 200 CDs.I consider this, along with a nominal amount of money dedicated to ads / boosting posts on social media — which add up and are a necessary evil to get your content seen (even by people who have already "liked" you ... but don't get me started).  This includes promoting this IndieGoGo campaign.  to be a basic cost to promoting the album and getting the word out.  Overall, this represents about 9% of the overall campaign objective.I'll be offering a limited number of CDs, which I will sign, as a perk.  The rest will be sent to music managers at radio stations across the country. Promotional SwagI'm going to be creating merchandise related to this release that will include t-shirts, magnets and stickers.   These represent a good basic set of merch items that I think people will enjoy and be most likely to buy.  These items will use the artwork and logo I've designed for the album.  I want to do a run of these items of a sufficient size to make them as cost effective as I can. Below is the design I've created for the t-shirts based on the original acrylic painting used for the album artwork as a five color vector image appropriate for silk screen printing (well, 6 colors, but one is made transparent depending upon the t-shirt color).  To make the printing more economical it's actually 4 colors and half tones are used where possible — this leads to some subtle variations, but I think it's cool.As part of this campaign, I'm offering these items as perks as well.  Since there is a significant price break with the vendor I'm using at 125 t-shirts, this the number I costed out for each of the two styles I'm creating when I came up with the campaign budget (The assumption is that  some will be pre-ordered and I'll want to have decent initial inventory for the various sizes).  Similar considerations are in play for the magnets and stickers.  The swag items represents approximately 16% of the overall campaign target.  Music VideosOne of the primary objectives of this campaign will be to help fund the production of two music videos associated with this album.  Creating a compelling visual component is one of the most effective means to get people aware of and engaged with new music.  It also offers opportunities for additional exposure through other channels such as film festivals.  Furthermore it's just something I enjoy doing.By pre-ordering, in addition to supporting myself and this album, you'll also be supporting the independent artists that will be helping me create these videos. Given some particular opportunities available to me, I've already started to move forward with these projects.  For instance, I've already shot some footage for a live action video for the "The Albatross Song" because a fantastic and visually sumptuous location was available to me for this shoot in December.  The host of this venue helped make the affair into a community building event with an open mic for local musicians in order to create the sort of crowd atmosphere I wanted for this piece.  It was a great night and I'm looking forward to seeing the results as the videographer starts editing the footage together. I'm also working with an artist to create a video for "Lighthouse at the Edge of the World" that I will be releasing as single before the release of the full album.  This video will combine animation with live video featuring the California Coast.  Developing professional quality videos is expensive.  In addition to the cost of hiring a videographer or animator and other personnel and production costs, there is the further cost of promoting the videos on social media to help get the visibility and the engagement this work deserves.  Having released music videos in the past, I know from experience simply posting them isn't enough to get views — the various social platforms make it a lot harder to go "viral" these days and having spent money and time creating these pieces, it's worth planning in costs to promote them as well.  Fortunately, I now have data points from previous Facebook ad campaigns that will help me target audiences more effectively for these releases for a DIY approach to promotion (for a more "advanced" campaign option I am considering, see below).  In addition to purchasing Facebook and Instagram ads to promote these videos, I will be submitting them to various film festivals for which there are not insignificant entry fees and can add up as you select multiple categories — for instance for the Berlin Music Video festival I'm aiming to submit the video for Lighthouse at the Edge of the World, to enter both the "Best Animation" and "Best Video Category" will run me $60.  I've factored in these costs into the video creation budget.To get a sense of my creative vision when it comes to music videos, here is a previous video that I self funded:The L.A. Song(This video shot in Los Angeles with Button Up Productions) 
The cost of producing the music videos and doing a social media campaign accounts for over a quarter of the fundraising objective.  The costs are split between the two new videos, with the live action video taking a somewhat larger share of the budget than the animated video.
 
Advanced Promotional CostsI'm looking to engage a professional PR firm to help me garner press for the album as well place place singles and the videos in music blogs and playlists.  These campaigns run over the course of a number of weeks or months and are quite expensive — although the pricing varies depending upon the agency as does what services are included in various packages they offer.  However something along the lines of ~$1300  month for a minimum of 3 months is a common price point, though there are usually lower cost options.  In doing this sort of promotion I would expect to also need to do a professional photoshoot which is going to run around $300.  So I've budgeted a quarter of my fundraising goal towards this portion of the campaign.There is debate within the music community as to the efficacy of using such agencies, but I feel that given the effort I've put into the music, I owe it and myself the opportunity that someone with real expertise can provide in finding it an audience.   Recording CostsThen there's the money it took to create the album itself.The remaining approximately 24% of the campaign budget will go towards the cost of recording, mastering and digital distribution of the album and its singles.  Recouping these costs will allow me to engage in future recording projects. RisksSince at this point the music is already recorded, there's no risk that you won't receive the music as a digital download.  But by buying the music as a pre-order, you'll be helping with its release into world in a way that will help me maximize its exposure and success.  With the music videos there are inherent risks in the creative process — such as being subject to schedules of other creatives involved.  But at this point we already have a significant amount of footage for the first video done so it's largely a matter of editing at this point.  I expect the initial edit to be completed in mid-late January.  We are still in the early stages of the 2nd video's production, but we have an end date scheduled for early February to target a particular film festival.Some of the merch items might end up varying slightly as I inevitably end up tweak them a bit (especially in regards to the t-shirts), but I don't expect the basic design choices to change.Even if I meet my fundraising goals, allowing me to do the full PR campaign, there's no guarantee that such a promotional campaign will result in placements and the resulting additional exposure I'm looking for.  However, by helping with the campaign you'll be showing there's interest in my music and contributing to the overall story of how this music came to be.If I don't reach my funding goal, the promotional efforts will need to be scaled back and I will likely reassess the number of swag items I end up ordering.  Fortunately I took advantage of an IndieGoGo promotional discount so the fees for not hitting my goal are much less substantive. And Any Extra I Get?Extra money I receive above and beyond my target will be used in part towards ordering more swag so I can have it available as merch at shows and for selling on-line via bandcamp.  And for certain pieces, such as the magnets, there's a significant price break to be had for ordering in bulk beyond my current plan.Additionally, the more I receive, the more robust the online marketing campaign can be.  The more I can spend on a PR campaign, the better chance I'll have at placing the songs and videos in music blogs and Spotify playlists to reach a wider audience.Beyond that, you will be helping to fund my next recording project.Thank you for your support.- E.G.

story:
Heesun Lee and Jacquelyn Wells are Korean adoptee musicians based in NYC.

From the director of the music video:

"During my life as a Korean adoptee and a filmmaker of adoptee documentaries, I've never explored the stories of the women who give up their children hoping for a better life for them, as well as the women like my mother who adopt these children.  What drew me to "Lap" is the chance to visually represent these women in the context of an emotional and heartfelt song from two female adoptees.  It is an exciting opportunity and challenge." -Jon Maxwell

Jon Maxwell is a commercial and documentary filmmaker living in Los Angeles.  He's done two feature length docuseries on Korean adoption: AKA Dan 2014, and AKA Seoul 2016.  AKA Dan has amassed millions of views across youtube, Hulu, and DirectTV.  AKA Seoul was nominated for "Beat Feature Documentary" by the Los Angeles Press Club of journalists.  

 

Mpax  Music Productions wrote and  provided the beat inspired by Heesun’s idea. He is an incredible producer and worked closely with Heesun and Jacquelyn to make this song.

 

Short Summary

Imagine a child given up for adoption.

Imagine the birth mother having to make that unspeakable sacrifice.

Imagine the adoptive mother waiting patiently for a miracle.

From Musician/Rapper Heesun Lee:

I wanted to write a song which provided an understanding for every person involved in the adoption process.  I felt it was important to let you “see” these unheard stories come alive. After I wrote the rap, I reached out to fellow friend and singer-songwriter, Jacquelyn Wells. Jacquelyn, also a Korean adoptee, wrote the beautiful piano, lyrics, and vocals to the hook and ending of the song, and together we made something we are both extremely proud of. Already the rough draft version has brought many people, adopted and not, to tears. We feel we have something powerful here.

The Impact

I am dedicated, along with Jacquelyn and Jon, to create a video that can change our perception on a topic that deeply affects so many of us. This song dives into issues that are rarely, if ever, discussed in the mainstream media. We need to support artists who are baring their souls in the midst of trying times, because it can help others heal. “Lap” is dedicated towards understanding the vulnerability and humanity in women, no matter what age or color we represent.

If this song or message speaks to you, we would be greatly appreciative of your generosity! We promise you that once this song visually comes to life, it will move mountains on so many levels. It is also promoting female unity and empowerment in a male dominated industry!

 

What We Need

  • As artists, we do not have the funds to make a stellar music video. 
  • We want actors to play the roles of these women, so people can truly feel the emotions behind this song.  We need camera, crew, equipment, locations, food for the crew, etc.   
  • All funds will go to the people and production needs involved in helping us make this music video the best that it can be.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share, share, share!  Spread the word about this project and the story we want to tell!
  • Live in NYC and have a skill that could help us? Reach out! jacquelynwellsmusic@gmail.com

story:
SUMMARY

Hi! I am Jen Kerner (performer name Joey Grace). I am a full time special education teacher, but a musician at heart, with the dream to release a full length album, make music videos, and end up on some of the grandest stages in the world, performing with top notch acts!

WHAT I NEED AND WHAT YOU'LL GET

My goal is to raise $15,000 to pay for music video production and studio time. You'll get fun perks by donating!

  • If I do not reach my goal of $15,000 the money will still be put toward pursuing my dreams with music.

THE IMPACT

After 21 years of working with the special needs community, I am finally focusing on ME and MY dreams in life. I love singing, writing music, and performing live! Your contribution will help me to continue with this dream. I will continue to make content that will be ethereal, beautiful, and interesting to watch and listen to.

THE CHALLENGES

I've already spent my own money to record my EP, create a website, register my songs, and much more. It really adds up after a while! Your contribution will help me to move forward as I pursue music goals. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Tell your friends about my campaign, and share the link to my campaign. Thank you so much!

story:
'Jasmine' is a quintet which I formed in my final year at Leeds College of Music. We perform my own compositions, which are heavily inspired by a blend of jazz and hip-hop.        

 

In July, we recorded a nine-track EP, which I was able to fund myself. Now that the tracks are down, we need your help with the next stage!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             Having the EP available on vinyl is something that is very important to me; there is something about vinyl that makes me appreciate listening to music so much more. For me, having a physical copy of an album or EP on vinyl makes listening to an artist feel very special.  

 

In July 2018, I graduated from LCoM. During my time there I was able to discover a wide variety of music, both from the Jazz genre and other genres, such as hip-hop and afro-beat.              

This allowed me to realise the types of music that I am passionate about, and really come into my own as an artist.                                                                                                                                   

 

I have been very lucky to work with Tight Lines, which is an independent record label based in Leeds. They have supported the band a lot and have given us some really cool opportunities, which we are very grateful for! In May, we recorded a live session with them, performing one of our original tunes entitled 'It'll Happen', which was one of the first recordings of our music that could be found online.                                                                                                                         We were also honoured to appear on 'To Be Here Now', which is a jazz compilation vinyl, showcasing some of the most exciting original jazz music being produced in Leeds right now.       I have lived in Leeds my entire life and the rest of the band are also based here. I am incredibly proud to be from Leeds and to be a part of it's vibrant and ever-expanding/evolving Jazz scene. Listening to 'To Be Here Now' and hearing our tune 'Cold Sweat' on vinyl for the first time was a memorable moment for me, which is why I am so eager to have our debut EP released on vinyl. 

 

The EP includes a blend of jazz and hip-hop music which creates a current but unique sound. I am also excited to develop the use of live electronics in my music, through Ableton Live, which will take our music to a whole new level.

 

Backing from the public will enable us to pay for the EP to be pressed to vinyl and CD.  It will also allow us to commission an artist to design our album artwork and will pay for the production of merchandise.                                                                                                                                       Every donation counts! No matter how big or small, as it will push us closer to our £1k goal!

 

You can also choose to purchase a pre-sale of the EP (on digital, vinyl and CD), merchandise, or one of our special bundles, which includes limited edition items!

 

If we can reach our goal, we can share with you our nine-track EP on vinyl, which will be the result of all of the hard work, love, and dedication we have put into this project over the past year and a half.

 

Please help us to make this happen!

story:
What is Dark-Pop: its purpose is to finally discuss some tough sometimes traumatizing subject matter in a creepily fun way: pop music. I wanted to give the opportunity to pop listeners to finally feel something real and relatable, the way I felt during the emo wave in the early 2000s. I feel like fans in other genres get to cathartically rage about heavier topics such as suicide, social anxiety, self-deprecation or harm; and their audiences are healthier because of that – they're able to expel this tension from their psyches. That’s what’s so therapeutic about music. Pop tends to be about glamor, happiness, attraction, fun – but you can have fun and still be honest, and that’s why people really resonate with my project. It’s something I’ve been humbled to hear on a number of occasions, that my lyrics are brutal, but the melodies and arrangements are so addicting and fun that people can’t stop singing along and falling in love with the stories being told. An emotionally repressed life is a bird in a cage, and I don’t want to continue that cycle in a craft that’s supposed to set people’s souls free. I want to be the hand unlatching the cage door for everyone.

My name is Ashley Sarah Beroukhim – but I go by Ashley Zarah for short. I’m an odd, redheaded, Iranian-American singer/songwriter and Dark-Pop performer hailing from Los Angeles, CA. I’m a mouthful to say the least. But my toils, triumphs and journey so far has led me here – to Boston, Massachusetts where I’ve been studying and creating at Berklee College of Music. I had quite a hard time figuring out who I am – it’s hard when the world around you seems to reject your will for happiness at every corner (lul*). I mean; bullies, culture and religion, mental illness, romance (lack thereof lol), drugs, anxiety, identity, alcohol (etc.) – the works. And yet there’s always been this music – these voices printed on CDs and singing in headphones telling us that things are getting better, and that we're not toxic by birth but our environments could be – music assured me that I was going to make it out. Music strengthened my optimism, my drive, my ability to see clearer. It strengthened me, and when you’re strong, you can strengthen others. I’m here to prove that no pain is worth the disposal of a life. We’re gonna burns what irks you and dance through the fire of it on stage. But let’s get to that stage.

$3,000 is what it takes to send my music to important bloggers, promoters, influencers, and critics for the rest of the year; it’s what it takes to get me onto Spotify playlists and reach people who don’t know me or don’t have mutual friends with me who see what you share when you hit that share button; $3,000 is gonna add to my music video fund (that I’m so close to reaching already!). I get reviews, features on publications, exposure across the nation. I saw a hilariously embittering comic the other day that we pay everyone for their professions with money, but we pay artists with exposure… it’s a sad truth, but as of now, it’s the truth. So rather than moping over it – we gotta work with it.

I understand what I’m asking for, and that I’m hoping to achieve that year's fund in a mere 60 days – but! I am overcome with gratitude already by any hand that’s reaching to help mine. And whatever we do build together will be sent to this cause, nothing raised will be spent on anything else but marketing this music campaign.

The Ashley Zarah brand stands for unity, stands for empathy, and for patience – patience for others and for ourselves. Proceeds from my merch are sent to suicide prevention programs. I stand beside the SandCloud community as an ambassador for environmental/animal conservation and marine health. Being a musician is not about US; it is about the world that raised us and making sure we take care of it; including all those with a beating heart and a will to live (like you human being things that are reading this). I know my music can do something for people, but if no one hears it, then its function is lost. If a tree falls in an empty forest, right? So let’s make sure that there’s an audience when the music drops.

Thank you all!! Hit me up with any questions or any general feelings/thoughts/comments you may have. Let’s do this ;]
story_txt:
What is Dark-Pop: its purpose is to finally discuss some tough sometimes traumatizing subject matter in a creepily fun way: pop music. I wanted to give the opportunity to pop listeners to finally feel something real and relatable, the way I felt during the emo wave in the early 2000s. I feel like fans in other genres get to cathartically rage about heavier topics such as suicide, social anxiety, self-deprecation or harm; and their audiences are healthier because of that – they're able to expel this tension from their psyches. That’s what’s so therapeutic about music. Pop tends to be about glamor, happiness, attraction, fun – but you can have fun and still be honest, and that’s why people really resonate with my project. It’s something I’ve been humbled to hear on a number of occasions, that my lyrics are brutal, but the melodies and arrangements are so addicting and fun that people can’t stop singing along and falling in love with the stories being told. An emotionally repressed life is a bird in a cage, and I don’t want to continue that cycle in a craft that’s supposed to set people’s souls free. I want to be the hand unlatching the cage door for everyone.
My name is Ashley Sarah Beroukhim – but I go by Ashley Zarah for short. I’m an odd, redheaded, Iranian-American singer/songwriter and Dark-Pop performer hailing from Los Angeles, CA. I’m a mouthful to say the least. But my toils, triumphs and journey so far has led me here – to Boston, Massachusetts where I’ve been studying and creating at Berklee College of Music. I had quite a hard time figuring out who I am – it’s hard when the world around you seems to reject your will for happiness at every corner (lul*). I mean; bullies, culture and religion, mental illness, romance (lack thereof lol), drugs, anxiety, identity, alcohol (etc.) – the works. And yet there’s always been this music – these voices printed on CDs and singing in headphones telling us that things are getting better, and that we're not toxic by birth but our environments could be – music assured me that I was going to make it out. Music strengthened my optimism, my drive, my ability to see clearer. It strengthened me, and when you’re strong, you can strengthen others. I’m here to prove that no pain is worth the disposal of a life. We’re gonna burns what irks you and dance through the fire of it on stage. But let’s get to that stage.
$3,000 is what it takes to send my music to important bloggers, promoters, influencers, and critics for the rest of the year; it’s what it takes to get me onto Spotify playlists and reach people who don’t know me or don’t have mutual friends with me who see what you share when you hit that share button; $3,000 is gonna add to my music video fund (that I’m so close to reaching already!). I get reviews, features on publications, exposure across the nation. I saw a hilariously embittering comic the other day that we pay everyone for their professions with money, but we pay artists with exposure… it’s a sad truth, but as of now, it’s the truth. So rather than moping over it – we gotta work with it.
I understand what I’m asking for, and that I’m hoping to achieve that year's fund in a mere 60 days – but! I am overcome with gratitude already by any hand that’s reaching to help mine. And whatever we do build together will be sent to this cause, nothing raised will be spent on anything else but marketing this music campaign.
The Ashley Zarah brand stands for unity, stands for empathy, and for patience – patience for others and for ourselves. Proceeds from my merch are sent to suicide prevention programs. I stand beside the SandCloud community as an ambassador for environmental/animal conservation and marine health. Being a musician is not about US; it is about the world that raised us and making sure we take care of it; including all those with a beating heart and a will to live (like you human being things that are reading this). I know my music can do something for people, but if no one hears it, then its function is lost. If a tree falls in an empty forest, right? So let’s make sure that there’s an audience when the music drops.
Thank you all!! Hit me up with any questions or any general feelings/thoughts/comments you may have. Let’s do this ;]

story:
My name is Kare Strong and I'm a singer-songwriter.  In Nov. 2017 Grammy-nominated multi-instrumentalist, producer and teacher Josh Goforth,  and I released a first collaboration, an album of my original songs, called Rivers of Love, (Songs for the Whole Family). To my enormous happiness it won several awards. We are in the midst of recording a second album of 14 new original songs for the whole family called Beneath the Cherry Tree.  It reflects my growth as a songwriter and Josh's correspondingly more intricate and ever beautiful instrumental arrangements. On the album he plays fiddle, banjo, mandolin, guitar, bass, mountain dulcimer and piano. 

 

Throughout the past 2 years I have been  writing new songs and taking them to my music lessons with Josh. He would often send me home  with very specific homework to do. When I did the homework, the songs sometimes crossed over an invisible line that my heart registered. Beauty makes the heart so glad! These songs come from a felt sense of a "calling," something I feel I have been given to share with the world that is unique to me.

Making an album of this quality is very expensive. This is why I need your help. The budget for this project is about $10,000. (I'm hoping to raise half that amount.)  Making this album requires  many days in the recording studio, special guest musician/guest studio fees, mixing, mastering, graphic arts layout, CD manufacturing and more.  I am hoping to raise $5,000 because this amount will cover the recording studio and the mastering costs. It will hugely help me afford to pay for this project. 

If by chance more than $5,000 is raised, I plan to use any additional contributions to get this album into the hands of organizations that can sell it to earn money to help children afford music lessons and acquire musical instruments. I wish every child could have the financial means to take music lessons and learn to play a chosen instrument. 

The songs are imbued with a love for nature and are chock full  of beloved animal characters. Trees and flowers can talk and they tell their beautiful stories. And you will find a faery or two doing wondrous things. The songs celebrate life. They affirm the Goodness at the heart of everything. They are love songs for the whole family. 

Please watch the video and consider purchasing a CD/Digital download in advance. I can't wait to send you this music. I appreciate any and all support.

 

Thank you so very much!

Kare Strong

Please feel free to visit www.karestrongmusic.com

Please reach out to me at karestrongmusic@gmail.com

Another way you can help is to share this campaign on social media, with friends, family, co-workers, anyone who might enjoy this music. Indiegogo has easy ways to share. 

Thank you ever so much for your support! 

Thank you to my sister's husband John Tweedy and to my sister Beret Strong for the wonderful gift of making the Beneath the Cherry Tree  video for me. 

 

​

story:
Sam Densmore is a Portland, OR based songwriter with a new release (Black Velvet Unicorn) and European tour on the way in October of 2019.

Paul Paresa contributed keyboards to Black Velvet Unicorn, and will be joining Sam on tour in support of the new release! Sam and Paul are raising money to offset travel expenses while touring in Europe this Fall. Your contribution will help keep them safe and warm while traveling !

Sam and Paul are hoping to raise $3,000 to offset the cost of air travel, car rental, and lodging while traveling in Europe. 

Special, unique merchandise items - Glow In The Dark Black Velvet Unicorn Tour Tee Shirts, Bandannas, Autographed CDS and Tour Posters are available in the perks section. 

All funds raised here will go to offset Sam and Pauls travel expenses while touring in Europe. 

Supporting independent artists feels good! The DIY spirit is alive, but flourishes only with your support . Sam and Paul are 100% self funded, and have worked hard to make this music and bring the live show to the world.

Thanks for taking the time to consider helping Sam and Paul on their upcoming tour!

If you aren't able to contribute at this time, please further our cause by using the Indiegogo share tools and sharing this page on social media ! ​

story:
Since I was a small girl growing up in Indiana, music has been my trusted friend and co-pilot in navigating the waves of life. Studying opera and violin-making at Indiana University’s Jacobs School of Music, and later continuing my studies in Parma, Italy, the language of music continued to reveal itself as the most graceful and expansive way to pour my soul into this world. Five years ago when Kundalini yoga and the power of mantra walked into my life, I had a deep knowing in my cells that music truly is medicine. 

 

I am birthing a devotional music album, and I need your support! I truly believe the simplest tools we have… our bodies, our breath, and our voices... are divinely designed to heal our unique selves. Through the study and application of western and eastern sound technology, I have spent over 20 years learning how combinations of movement, breathing patterns, singing, and chanting can rewire our neurotemplates, rewrite our stories, elevate our spirits, and help us embody the change we wish to see.

 

 

We have all experienced trauma to some degree within our lives, whether it be our health, within our families, from a natural disaster, or vicariously as a caregiver. Epigenetics shows we carry ancestral trauma from 14 previous generations within our DNA. We store these emotions, experiences, and environments within the cellular memory of our bodies, and need various modalities to self-regulate our nervous systems back to a state of equilibrium.

 

“Life is a challenge, rhythm is the answer.”

~ Yogi Bhajan

​

Our nervous system craves the beat of our mother’s heart, being rocked in our father’s arms, the crashing waves of an ocean, the steadiness of a tribal drum. Through the practice of Kundalini yoga we breathe, chant, and move our bodies in community rhythm. On a cellular and energetic level, we release the emotions and conditioned ways of thinking that no longer serve us, and make way for grace.

​

Mantra is the personal, kinesthetic experience of how sound vibrations affect us on a neurological, biochemical, emotional, and spiritual level through the simple movement of the tongue, mouth, and breath. Mantra can be thought of as a telephone number or computer code. It is the use of sound to ‘bio-hack’ our own system and rewire ourselves to notice and nourish joy, compassion, empathy, peace, fulfillment, and purpose in our lives. 'Man' means mind and 'Tra' means wave. Chanting mantra is like the purifying, repetitive waves of the ocean, or a refreshing shower for our overstimulated, looping, monkey-mind.

 

​

 

“It is similar to striking a note on a stringed instrument. In other words, as you vibrate, the Universe vibrates with you.” ~ Yogi Bhajan

​

Modern science agrees with what ancient mystics have always known:  everything is in a state of vibration, from the electrons spinning around the nucleus of an atom, to the distant movement of planets. This sacred, ancient, ever-vibrating, ever-permeating sound is the glue that keeps everything humming in divine timing, connects us to our community and loved ones, and connects us to our inner wisdom.

 

There is power in our voice. We shape our collective reality by the stories we tell our communities and children. We shape our lives by the stories we tell ourselves. When we utilize the technology of mantra to regulate our nervous system back to a place of neutrality, balance, inner peace, equilibrium,   h o m e o s t a s i s… we come home to our beloved selves. This is the journey we are all walking together. Thank you for taking this next step with me. 

 

By your side,

Pavan 

Max Ribner ~ Music Production, Flugelhorn

Remmington Wilcox ~ Videographer

Olivia Ashtonn ~ Photographer

story:
Hello friends and fans. My name is Kevin Bujo Jones. I'm a percussionist with a plethora of experience and a veteran of the music industry. I started my career in 1972, at the age of 13 touring with a group signed to All Platinum Records (later Sugar Hill Records). From there I went on to tour and record with Archie Shepp, The Isley Brothers, Whitney Houston and many other icons in the music industry. In 1999 I met pianist and composer Kelvin Sholar and we formed a group called Tenth World with a host of young, innovative musicians. Tenth World plays music that can be described as having the melodic and harmonic sensibilities of Jazz and Soul infused with the rhythms of the African Diaspora.  The compositions are a synthesis of our shared experiences and influences. We recorded 3 CD's, 2 of which were picked up by Motema Music. The albums got rave reviews from Jazz Times, Downbeat Magazine and Jazz.com. After a brief period of inactivity we are now back and ready to record again. 

This time we are going independent which is great for freedom and creative control. But with that freedom comes the huge cost of making an album. All of the funds we are seeking will go directly to studio time, mixing, mastering, manufacturing, marketing and paying hired musicians that round out the ensemble. 

We are calling this effort Tenth World "Rising" not just because we are resurrecting our Tenth World project but both Kelvin and I are rising from some severe medical hardships. About five years ago I had to have brain surgery due to a large subdural hematoma. It took me almost a year to even walk without a cane. About a year and a half ago Kelvin passed out on stage in Berlin, Germany and was rushed to the hospital due to a seizure. We are both grateful and humbled to be alive today. The one thing it taught us was that life is short and we value each and every moment. So at this time we feel that we cannot wait for someone or a label to do this for us. We are grabbing our future by reins and steering it in the direction of good.

We want to thank each and every one of you for your kindness, love and support in the past, in the present and in the future. We are making music to uplift people. We are healers because music is the way that we have healed ourselves. 

Please help out in whatever way you can. If you can't donate at this time, please share this on your social media platforms and through email. 

Once again, thank you from the bottom of my heart and let's all "Rise" together. 

Kevin Bujo Jones

story:
We are The High Ground...

                                          and we're excited to be launching our very first campaign on Indiegogo! For those of you who are not familiar with our story, while on summer break from school in 2017, vocalist Andrew Parker, bassist Matt Brown, and guitarist Jack Brown started the band as three close friends writing classic rock & roll influenced, pop-punk tunes.  We began to perform locally and caught the attention of regulars and music enthusiasts for our catchy hooks, virtuoso instrumentation, and the genuine soul-drenched vocals and charisma of frontman Parker. In late 2017, we entered the studio to record a 4-track mixtape called Concrete. Following the release of the EP, we gained momentum and earned coveted performance slots on the main stage of the annual Florida Music Festival, and even the local date of the iconic Vans Warped Tour.

We're very proud of our debut EP Concrete, but with the addition of our drummer Dillon Smith, about a hundred live shows under our belts, along with natural maturing, we've grown tremendously since those early days.  Our musicianship and songwriting has advanced and our sound has evolved. Our fan base has exploded and now it's time to show the world what The High Ground is capable of, let's rock!

 

We Need Your Help!

Our first and second singles from our upcoming EP (When It Rains, It Pours & Swan Song) have been released, along with music videos for each song. The remaining tracks are fully recorded, produced, mastered, and will be released on September 20th, 2019. 

The purpose of this campaign is to help us raise money toward the recording and production costs we have already invested (which exhausted us a bit financially), as well as to provide additional funds needed to help us properly market and promote the release, and most importantly - continue this whole THG operation. We'll also be making additional upgrades to take our live performances to the next level.

What's the money for specifically? We put some thought into this and came up with a plan:

Recording and Production Costs - 30% of goal

  • Tracking, Editing, Tuning, Mixing, and Mastering
  • Album art design
  • Physical CD Production
  • Digital Distribution Fees
  • Copyright Fees

 

​Marketing and Promotion Costs - 30% of goal

  • Advertising and Social Media Promotion
  • Music videos for at least two songs
  • Photo shoots and promo videos
  • EP Release Event (9/28)

 

​Campaign and Other Expenses - 40% of goal

  • Campaign Merchandise
  • Shipping Costs
  • Campaign Fees
  • Tax, Legal, and Administrative Fees
  • Gear upgrades for live performances

​

​What's In It For You?

PERKS! To thank you for your contribution, we're offering:

  • Early streaming access to full EP (at least one week prior release)
  • Autographed CDs
  • T-Shirts, Hats, and Hoodies, and more
  • Personalized Video Cover Songs*
  • Release Party VIP Access*
  • Your Own Private Gig (Orlando area only)*

Remember, you can also choose to back the campaign with a contribution only (no perk ) if you'd just like to donate.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you aren't able to contribute financially, we need help from our fans!  Help us spread the word by using the sharing tools built-in to this campaign page.  LISTEN to our music on your favorite music service, FOLLOW US, LIKE, and SHARE on social media, and ATTEND our live shows!

Thank you so much for your support ~ we can't wait to share our music with you!

The High Ground

Jack, Andrew, Matthew, and Dillon

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Martina Lynch and I am a Hip Hop and Spoken Word Artist. I have been chasing my dream of changing lives through music since I was 15 years old with little resources. With the help of a local company Taharka Brothers, M.U.A Morgan Elaine, Dewmore Poetry and support from friends and family I was able to tour the east coast. Performing on big stages such as BET'S 106 and park and being selected for two ted talks where I was able to share my poetry and inspire so many!
  • Now it is time to take it up a notch! I have been able to reach success in my hometown and touch the lives of many through my hip hop and poetry workshops where I work one on one with children who aspire to do poetry. Now I want to take my passion, voice and team nationwide! Music is such a powerful tool when it comes to connecting with people. I believe funding a tour and developing my label will create a great opportunity for so many like me!
  • You will be helping me to bring a real game changing label into the mainstream. There aren't enough opportunities for artists especially from small towns like Baltimore. If you aren't able to get your music to a major label there's a big chance you will have many hurdles to overcome. With the help of this campaign I will be able to finish what I started and show other independent artist that people really do want change and to see something different.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise $15,000! We will be putting $8,000 into travel expenses so that we can be able to travel for a little over two months performing in over 8 cities! We will also put $2,000 into promotion and merchandise. We know to get your voice heard nationwide we will need the promotion and we will need to connect with the fans face to face. Finally we will need $5,000 to build our own studio where independent artists in the area will be able to record.
  • Whoever donates $5 or more will receive a mix tape from me and a original lip gloss from Morgan. If you donate $10 or more you will receive a shout out on the next album. If you donate 20$ or more you will receive free entry to the next show! 
  • If we do not reach our entire goal we will work with what we have to make it happen!

The Impact

  • There are so many artists, poets and musicians trying to find a way to make money doing what they love. I have been working a 9 to 5 job as well as chasing my dream. I recently quit my job to take on music full time. I've decided to take a chance on myself and I really need the support of my peers so that I can launch my label and create opportunities for others! You will be funding one of the greatest labels in the game!
  • I won the 1st ever adidas open mic series where I was able to have a one on one with HIP HOP legend Pusha T. After hearing my message and my music he says he believes I have the power to change hiphop. I believe I do too and that I can with your help!

Risks & Challenges

  • Growing up in Baltimore. i have taken advantage of every opportunity that has brought me closer to my dream and even though it has gotten me further it hasn't gotten me where I need to be. Being a Woman in HIP HOP has been an up an down roller coaster for me because even though I'm recognized for my talent, I don't always get the assistance I deserve if I am not over sexualizing myself. I have been told many times that if I were to promote myself as more sexy than I would receive help with promotion and shows. I want to follow my dreams and still be able to be myself. I don't want to wait on a major label or manager to tell me that I'm finally sexy enough or good enough. With your help I want to create that opportunity for myself!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, we would really appreciate you getting the word out! Tell a friend to tell a friend!!
story_txt:
Short Summary

My name is Martina Lynch and I am a Hip Hop and Spoken Word Artist. I have been chasing my dream of changing lives through music since I was 15 years old with little resources. With the help of a local company Taharka Brothers, M.U.A Morgan Elaine, Dewmore Poetry and support from friends and family I was able to tour the east coast. Performing on big stages such as BET'S 106 and park and being selected for two ted talks where I was able to share my poetry and inspire so many!
Now it is time to take it up a notch! I have been able to reach success in my hometown and touch the lives of many through my hip hop and poetry workshops where I work one on one with children who aspire to do poetry. Now I want to take my passion, voice and team nationwide! Music is such a powerful tool when it comes to connecting with people. I believe funding a tour and developing my label will create a great opportunity for so many like me!
You will be helping me to bring a real game changing label into the mainstream. There aren't enough opportunities for artists especially from small towns like Baltimore. If you aren't able to get your music to a major label there's a big chance you will have many hurdles to overcome. With the help of this campaign I will be able to finish what I started and show other independent artist that people really do want change and to see something different.

The Impact

You will be funding one of the greatest labels in the game!
I won the 1st ever adidas open mic series where I was able to have a one on one with HIP HOP legend Pusha T. After hearing my message and my music he says he believes I have the power to change hiphop. I believe I do too and that I can with your help!


Risks & Challenges
Growing up in Baltimore. i have taken advantage of every opportunity that has brought me closer to my dream and even though it has gotten me further it hasn't gotten me where I need to be. Being a Woman in HIP HOP has been an up an down roller coaster for me because even though I'm recognized for my talent, I don't always get the assistance I deserve if I am not over sexualizing myself. I have been told many times that if I were to promote myself as more sexy than I would receive help with promotion and shows. I want to follow my dreams and still be able to be myself. I don't want to wait on a major label or manager to tell me that I'm finally sexy enough or good enough. With your help I want to create that opportunity for myself!

Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren't able to donate, we would really appreciate you getting the word out! Tell a friend to tell a friend!!

story:
Short Summary

 

My name is Beau Cody. I am a musician and entertainer from the island of Oahu and recently I made a big jump!

Ever since I was little, I always wanted to create music. I started a band and fell in love with performing live. I always wanted to tour, write music and tell stories.

So I moved from my hometown to the show capital of the world, Las Vegas. Here is my performance schedule if you are in Vegas or California . I have been playing a lot of shows but something is calling me back into the studio. To create.

A new music project / album. A Reggae + Pop + Soul record that I am currently working on and it's called Waves. I'm also working with a Hawaii local artist on the visuals for the album. And a live performance of the project so look out for videos and song samples coming soon.



If you've heard me perform before or seen me sing on-line, consider donating to making this a reality. Help me record my album.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

 

My goal is to raise $8,000. This will help me get started with studio time so I can get started next month. I will also be working with a very talented Hawaii local artist on exclusive art work and visuals for the album. There are only a few days left of the campaign so please donate if you can.

 

 

How To Be A Part

 

 

1) Scroll through and select one (or more) of the REWARD PACKAGES to the 
right ------------------------------------------->

You can pledge anywhere from $5 - $1000 (or more), depending on what reward you want.

If you find a package that you want but you want to give more, you can edit the pledge amount.

2) Click "Support Project" (the green button on the top right of the page)

3) Enter the Pledge Amount you want.

4)Choose the reward package you want and then make the pledge.


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT

 

 

In Closing

 

 

Thank you for supporting me chase my dream. I have been performing and working on music for a long time. I'm going all in. I'm performing in bars and venues in Las Vegas working on an amazing live performance and it's time to record my first album.

If you know me personally or seen me perform before, this is a way to help me.

Also please follow my journey on instagram and my website.

 

Instagram: www.instagram.com/musicnwaves

Website: www.beaucody.com

Facebook: www.facebook.com/beaucodymusic

Periscope (live streams): www.periscope.tv/beaucody




Let's do this.
 



- Beau Cody

story:
Our Album

We're Cardboard Rocketship, a four piece contemporary folk band based in Brooklyn, NY. We've been on quite the journey together so far, having released a five-song EP this past March and a single in July, all the while playing shows in and around NYC. 

And now, the time has come to embark on our next and biggest project yet: our debut album.

We're in the process of recording our debut full-length EP, and it's been a wonderfully exciting process. But the fact of the matter is that great records don't come cheap. We've been working with a very talented producer and engineering team in Harlem, NYC, and can't wait to finish the process. But for that, we need your help. 

What We Need & What You Get

We're recording twelve songs total. That's a lot of music! We're tracking banjo, guitar, cello, ukulele, and four-part vocals for every song, as well as arranging and adding percussion and piano in many of them. That studio time plus multiple mixes and masters of each song is shaping up to be a 400-hour project for our production team. We want to ensure that we pay them fairly for their time. 

When you contribute to our campaign, not only will you help us create a lasting version of our music, but you'll get some perks as well! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any monetary contribution helps so much, but if you're not in a place to donate financially right now, we'd greatly appreciate if you could share this campaign with your community, and follow @cardboardrocketship on Instagram to keep up with our upcoming shows and release info!

story:
^^^For MOBILE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the picture to see details/Rewards^^^ 

 For ONLINE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the picture to see details/Rewards>>>>>>

Lets Live in the moment & Create change that lasts. 

 

Royce Melleáux (Mell-ohh) is a Portland-based Roots/Soul/Rock ’n’ Roll band that believes every fan is a friend and every moment is a chance to spread happiness. We believe music has the power to unite communities and inspire meaningful change — not just now, but for generations to come. This is your chance to be a part of the journey.

 

We have an amazing opportunity to work with professionals from Portland and San Francisco — musicians, producers, arrangers and engineers who’ve worked with big names like Sammy Hager, Bob Weir of the Grateful Dead, Joey Ramone, Joe Satriani, Mazzy Star and Ronnie Spector, to name a few. They’re helping us put together our first album, Influencer/Observer.

 

 ForONLINE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the pictureto see details/Rewards>>>>>>

We are:

  • Mckay Everhart, Lead Vocals / Keys / Rhythm Guitar
  • Quin Wiltshire, Drums / Percussion 
  • Ryan Stadler, Bass Guitar 
  • JD Erikson, Saxophone

 

 For ONLINE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the picture to see details/Rewards>>>>>>

 

In 2016, we started jamming in a garage. Little did we know this would become a never-ending obsession to create genre-bending music. Royce Melleáux was founded with a binary thought of engagement and persona. We want to create fun and energy-filled experiences and offer a powerful sense of self-reflection and an understanding of where our music is individually and as a whole. 

 

This idea has evolved into being a band that would not only create a great sound but also bring people together to create a more hopeful world. A huge dream of ours when starting this group was to impact our community, the nation and eventually the world by sharing our music and supporting worthy causes. Over the past couple years, we’ve spent numerous hours arranging and writing material that we feel can really bring change and joy to people’s lives. 

 

We’ve chosen 12 songs from our catalog to share with you all and we decided it’s time to bring these songs to people who can join us in making an amazing product to share with the world and take us to the next level. We want to make the most of this incredible opportunity.

 

Our goal is to connect and build a community like no other. By featuring groundbreaking collaboration in musical moments as well as many sectors life. Through our music and live experiences we feel we can create true happiness through meaningful interactions and beautifully captured moments. The music of Influencer/Observer means everything to us, and we want you to be a part of it. Are you with us?

 

 For ONLINE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the picture to see details/Rewards>>>>>>

 

100% of every donation we receive will go toward:

 

  • Recording 
  • Mixing 
  • Editing 
  • Mastering
  • Video Production
  • Digital Distribution Fees
  • Marketing the Album 

 

When you make a donation, you’ll receive:

 

  • Shared love of our Project . You’ll help us make our first-ever professional studio recording!
  • Our new album. You’ll receive a selection of original songs that will give you hope, remind you of why we’re here together, fill your body with joy and make you feel like dancing the night away.
  • Love and gratitude. We’re beyond thankful that you would donate your hard-earned pay for a cause that we feel so strongly about. Hopefully, you’ll come to feel the same way. 
  • Amazing perks. We want to give you the best compensation for your generosity by designing perks that will make you feel just with your contribution. 

 

Join our cause to help us …

 

  • Share our story
  • Learn how we see the world 
  • Leave a lasting impression in the music industry 
  • Through the creative process explore sounds never heard before
  • Open minds and ears to unforeseen possibilities 
  • Make people move and dance 
  • To ROCK!

 

You’re appreciated, and we thank you!

If you aren't able to contribute, no problem. It’s a blessing that you’re here!

We would love if you could help us by:

1. .Sharing our campaign to spread the word 

2. Using Indiegogo’s amazing share tools

3. Talk about our campaign with friends and family! If you like our musical mission, please share with the people you love and tell them what we’re about.

 4. Share link over text and social media platforms. You’re the best! 

 

 For ONLINE USE... Select your perk, CLICK on the picture to see details/Rewards>>>>>>

story:
Help us finish this album of original songs featuring West African grooves, Latin rhythms, 80's synths, and rock attitude - the first full-length collaboration by Sean Dixon (SLV, Zammutto) and Josh B. Fox (Lamb B. Bear). 

We are raising money to finish this record of groove-rich and thoughtful songs about the world we live in now and what it might become. After a year of working on the music, this campaign is raising money for the final stages of the project, including:  

  • Musicians - Including horn players and back-up singers.
  • Studio fees - 2-3 days in a studio in New York to record vocals, horns, and other odds and ends.
  • Mixing and Mastering - Making the sounds we have captured pop and shine.

The Record

Ten years after making my first album (Lamb B. Bear's Eat What You Kill) in Chicago, I am writing, recording, and releasing my second - a collaboration with oldest friend Sean Dixon, that combines African and Latin rhythms with electronic pop and rock. It's got desert blues, Afrobeat, psychedelic Cumbia, American folk, electronic flash, rock, jazz, and one '80's synth-pop song, naturally. One way or another, it's mostly music to get you dancing first, thinking second.

The first stage began in December 2018, when I spent 8 days in New York City with Sean Dixon, who has carved out a name for himself working as a professional musician in New York for over 20 years. That first marathon session in New York produced 10 songs, in varying states of completion. Since then, Sean and I have worked remotely, fleshing them out with lyrics and additional arrangements. 

The Songs

Musically, most of the songs on the album use West African or Latin music as inspiration, ineluctably filtered through my American musical sensibilities. (Click here for a Spotify playlist of "inspiration" music.) Sean's tremendous playing and deep experience as a percussionist and bass player in these traditions is at the core of the album's sound. Lyrically, the album reflects some of the major problems of our age, from global warming to income inequality to social isolation, with a central theme at its heart - let's work together. Ultimately, if we do our job right, we will have made a record that is a blast to dance to. 

Below are short clips of four of the ten songs, followed by some insights into their genesis:

 

The Musicians

Josh B. Fox is a Chicago-based musician and writer. He runs the mixtape blog Faux Sounds and works by day as a nonprofit fundraiser. He grew up in Milwaukee in a musical household, playing folk and blues with his parents, Penny and Dave Fox. Their debut recording as a family band, Come Back Baby, will be self-released in January 2020. Credits on this record: Vocals, bass, guitar, keyboards, programing, ukulele, lyrics, composing, arranging, producing.

Sean Dixon is a New York-based composer, producer, drummer, percussionist, and bassist. Also from a musical household in Milwaukee, Sean has lived in New York City since 1994, playing with innumerable performers, including Gotye’s Ondioline Orchestra, Maxwell, Aloe Blaac, Doyle Bramhall II, Amy Helm, Miyamoto Is Black Enough, Andy Akiho, and Helga Davis. He served as the rhythmic backbone of the band Zammuto and co-leads the group SLV. He has studied with Guinea’s master drummer, M’Bemba Bangoura, and Bahia’s musician/capoeirista Mestre Kiki da Bahia and Grupo Ginga. Click here to check out his website.  Credits on the record: Drums, percussion, keyboards, composing, arranging, producing.

Famoro Dioubate was born in Conakry, Guinea into a griot family. He is the grandson of El Hadj Djelli Sory Kouyate, a living legend of the Manding balafon. Famoro is a guardian of traditions dating back to the 13th century in the ancient Mandé Empire. He played in several groups across West Africa including Mory Kante‘s orchestra. He lives in New York City, where he leads his band Kakande. Click here to hear his music on Bandcamp.  

Penny Fox is a Milwaukee-based blues and folk singer steeped in traditional American music, with a style all her own. This is her first time singing anything close to music that sounds like this. 

 

What other great musicians can your contribution help us get on the record?
